Award.AwardTitle: E2CDA: Type II: A new non-volatile electrochemical transistor as an artificial synapse: device scaling studies

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
One way to move computational power beyond the limits imposed by Moore's Law is to build computer architectures that mimic the brain. Indeed the brain is able to perform certain classes of complex computations, such as pattern recognition, very efficiently and using low power in spite of its inherent low speed. A novel device that exhibits some of the useful properties of the synapses found in the brain, such as ultra low-power switching, is explored in this proposal. Its working mechanism will be studied in detail and arrays of devices will be fabricated and miniaturized in order to provide a first step towards brain-like integrated circuits. Neuromorphic electronics, as these devices are often called, are a growing area of interest, therefore the research developed in this award has the potential to impact the future of the microelectronics industry and to produce a workforce trained for this emerging area. Finally, the optical properties of the device, which changes color upon operation, will allow to develop an outreach activity connecting art and science with the ultimate goal of attracting a more diverse student population to the area of materials science of electronic devices.
A new device based on polymeric semiconductors that mimics the functions of synapses, called ENODe (electrochemical neuromorphic organic device), will be studied. ENODes with ultra-low switching energy (<10 pJ), sub-mV switching voltage, retaining >500 individual states in a non-volatile fashion were demonstrated. The physical origin of such low switching energies and voltages will be investigated with the goal of optimizing the architecture of the ENODe. Furthermore, ENODes will be fabricated with an array of different materials that may enable a higher level of integration making use of solid-state technology to increase the switching speed beyond 1 kHz into the MHz range. Finally, using the same process used in traditional microelectronics, arrays of ENODes will be fabricated to test the reproducibility and the scaling laws of these new devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Novel materials and device architectures are required to address the inability of conventional transistor scaling to meet the increasingly demanding computational density and energy requirements of artificial neural networks (ANNs). In particular there is great interest in electronic devices that emulate the efficiency and power of the human brain. The connection between neurons (synapse) is the key of how the brain co-locates memory and computation, which is essential to the brain’s efficiency. With the funds provided by this award we developed a new electronic device that would play the role of the synapse in an ANN. The device, based on electrochemistry, is made with easily processable soft materials (polymers). We demonstrated an entirely solid-state device that switches at speeds compatible with conventional electronics, despite using ions. It shows exceptional resilience even at high temperatures (over a billion switching events at 90°C) and tunability. Our device also displays other characteristics that are very desirable for integration in ANNs, such as linearity, large resistance range and high average resistance. Furthermore, we developed a process to fabricate these devices that is compatible with conventional semiconductor microfabrication. As a consequence, we can envision being able to fabricate millions of devices and integrate them with Si-based electronics into new chips that mimic the brain (i.e. neuromorphic chips). Finally, the intrinsic biocompatibility of the materials we used allowed us to interface our electronic devices with neuron-like cells to demonstrate switching triggered by dopamine, a common neurotransmitter, secreted by these cells. This is a first step towards a new type of human-machine interface where biomolecules are used to control the state of an electronic device.
